Look into the tier 5 visa. It's called a 'youth mobility scheme'. Basically the new working holiday visa. You just need to apply from your home country and pay the $400. There's only a limited number of them available per year but neither me or my friends had any trouble getting one.

http://cwjobs.co.uk is good for technical roles
And http://reed.co.uk for a few more corporate roles
I came here on a 2 year work visa and am extending via a sponsored work visa, hopefully anyway :p

The hard part is getting people to give you the chance. If you don't have the educational merits then you really have to prove you can get the work done to a good standard. I was very fortunate to have been a founder for a successful company at home which I think is what got me in the door for most of my interviews moving here.
If you can show you can do the work required, why wouldn't they hire you? I say this however I've only worked with small agile teams in my career and I'm sure a more corporate environment would be different.

I have no formal training, but I've been working commercially for agencies and development houses for almost 7 years now. Well proven would be a combination of good references, code samples work experience.
Cost of living can vary, you can get a room in a flat (sharing with 3-4 other people) not far from the center of town for 550 p/month including bills. However you can easily spend 2,000 p/month to live in a nice house area. Food is probably the cheapest thing (compared to New Zealand where I came from) and rent is the heavy hitter.
If you can get a 35k+ salary you can live very comfortably here.

Sent a few copies of my CV via cwjobs.co.uk - once you're on some recruiters lists you get bombarded with interviews. I think the one I got wasn't advertised online but that's where the recruiter found me to start with :)

Can't recommend London enough. Contracting as an MVC PHP dev can get you 350 ($650 USD) per day, more if you're well proven. I've been here just over a year - I started on a 1 month contract which has been extended for 11 months now. Not to mention Europe is amazing in general.

I've used on a few projects this preloader, you just setup a json file with all the assests you want to preload, along with their size. It has callbacks for for everything so you can build your own loading system with it very easily :)
https://github.com/GianlucaGuarini/jQuery.html5loader

You could look at [SharpDevelop](http://www.icsharpcode.net/OpenSource/SD/). I use monodevelop exclusively as I've never had a project in Unity that's needed any advanced IDE features beyond auto-completion. I wish Jetbrains made a c# IDE instead of just resharper (which is great if you get VS).
Also, VS-express is free :)

Ahh I understand, what you need to do is take multiple screenshots with another camera then stitch them together :)
see here for a perfect example - http://forum.unity3d.com/threads/6465-large-screenshots-for-print?p=49364 viewfull=1#post49364

A higher resolution isn't going to show you more, the camera renders what it renders (and subsequently what your game can screen capture) not based on resolution but on the FoV and plane size. I think you're perhaps approaching this the wrong way. I would make a camera that shows a bigger area using the built in camera settings then activate and capture from that camera for your screenshot.

You need to type the variable in javascript as
public var myscript : Component
or in c#
public ClassName myscript;
where if the script you're adding is called PlayerController it would look like
public PlayerController myscript.

You don't need any kind of node / visual system to build a FSM though. I agree that if you need visual layouts to know how your code works you're doing something wrong.
Code in all cases, not matter the project should be easy to read and follow what it's doing.

For that in C# you will want to use a list, check our the answer of this question for a good example :)
http://answers.unity3d.com/questions/272755/multidimentional-array-for-inventory-style-system.html
I would also try to only check these blocks only when you know a change has been made to them, E.G. adding a block should trigger the blocks around it to check only once. obviously this is situational to your game and what it's doing :)
Best of luck

I would look at keeping an array, list or whatever you like of your objects. You may already be doing this to Instantiate them at positions, I'm not sure. Overlap sphere isn't that intense in terms of overhead...Unless you're checking this type of thing in update()
You can then easily just check the array if there's a block registered at that position.
It's very situational though. I would take time to try out both methods, if time is on your side :)
Always heard it as "ok, times up"
There's really no point in setting button variables every update frame :s

WRITING.TITLE: Quick question about USA esta for VWP. Maybe wrong subreddit.
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello! First off apologies if this is in the wrong section.
I traveled to the USA in November last year under the visa waiver program and all I had to do was submit an esta and pay the $14 fee.
These esta documents are valid for 2 years and there is some information you can update such as your arrival flight info and address while in the USA.
Ive updated this information as I'm now living in London and traveling back to the USA. However there is one field on my esta that I cannot update which is "Country you live in".
I'm currently on a work visa in the UK and everything on my esta now says I'll be flying in from London but because I cannot update this "Country you live in" field (which still says new zealand) I fear I might get bounced since I've technically been living in the UK for the last 7 months.
It's only $14, so I have no problem submitting a new esta with all correct info, but if someone with some knowledge on the matter can let me know that would be great!
again, sorry if this is the wrong subreddit.
cheers

well first off, typical programmers are not on 6 figure salaries like you say. A good chunk (and i'd argue a majority) of unity users are simply making games for a hobby and no matter how much time something saves $350 is just not possible.
